title: Where did Earth’s water come from? - Zachary Metz

options.label: A
options.text: Water was formed on Earth through a process called outgassing.

options.label: B
options.text: Water was present on Earth when the rock formed, but evaporated back into space due to high temperatures and lack of atmosphere.

options.label: C
options.text: Water was brought by comets and asteroids that bombarded the Earth over millions of years.

options.label: D
options.text: The Earth may have accumulated a substantial amount of water early on that was able to stay put, despite the lack of an atmosphere.

options.label: A
options.text: Water was formed on Earth through a process called outgassing.

options.label: B
options.text: Water was present on Earth when the rock formed, but evaporated back into space due to high temperatures and lack of atmosphere.

options.label: C
options.text: Water was brought by comets and asteroids that bombarded the Earth over millions of years.

options.label: D
options.text: The Earth may have accumulated a substantial amount of water early on that was able to stay put, despite the lack of an atmosphere.

title: Why it’s so hard to cure HIV/AIDS - Janet Iwasa

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary mode of HIV transmission?
What type of cells does HIV particularly target in the human body?
What is the term for the stage of HIV infection where the virus continues to replicate and destroy T cells, despite the patient appearing healthy?
What is the primary goal of antiretroviral therapy in HIV-positive patients?

options.label: B
options.text: To manage levels of HIV and prevent T cell counts from getting low

multiple-choice.question: What is the major catch with antiretroviral therapy?

options.label: A
options.text: It can only be taken for a short period

options.label: B
options.text: HIV-positive patients must keep taking their drugs for the rest of their lives

options.label: C
options.text: It is only effective for a certain age group

options.label: D
options.text: It is not effective against HIV that is hidden in the DNA of healthy T cells

multiple-choice.question: Why are current antiretroviral drugs not effective against HIV?

options.label: C
options.text: HIV hides out in the DNA of healthy T cells, which our current drugs cannot reach

multiple-choice.question: What term describes the dormant state of HIV genetic information in healthy T cells?
What is a major challenge in developing a cure for HIV?

options.label: B
options.text: Difficulty in accessing effective prevention and treatment in certain regions

options.label: C
options.text: Difficulty in understanding the biology of HIV

multiple-choice.question: What is one research approach to developing a cure for HIV?

options.label: A
options.text: Using a vaccine to prevent HIV transmission

options.label: B
options.text: Using genetic tools to cut the HIV DNA out of cells genomes altogether

options.label: C
options.text: Using a drug to activate all cells harboring the HIV genetic information

options.label: D
options.text: Using antiretroviral therapy to manage levels of HIV

options.label: A
options.text: It showed that HIV can be transmitted through casual contact

options.label: B
options.text: It showed that HIV can be transmitted through airborne transmission

options.label: C
options.text: It showed that a cure is possible, and that may give us what we need to beat HIV for good

options.label: D
options.text: It showed that antiretroviral therapy is not effective

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why HIV-positive patients must keep taking their antiretroviral drugs for the rest of their lives?

options.label: B
options.text: To manage levels of HIV and prevent T cell counts from getting low

options.label: C
options.text: Because the virus can make a deadly comeback without treatment

options.label: D
options.text: Because the drugs are not effective against HIV

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It would increase the number of people living with HIV

options.label: C
options.text: It would show that HIV can be transmitted through casual contact

options.label: D
options.text: It would show that HIV can be transmitted through airborne transmission

options.label: B
options.text: A condition where the thyroid gland is overactive

options.label: C
options.text: A condition where the thyroid gland produces too few hormones

options.label: D
options.text: A condition where the thyroid gland is underactive

options.label: A
options.text: Rapid weight loss, constant hunger, rapid heartbeat, feeling hot and sweaty, anxiety, difficulty sleeping

options.label: C
options.text: Weight gain, sluggishness, sensitivity to cold, swollen joints

options.label: D
options.text: To filter waste and toxins from the blood

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: To decrease the thyroid gland's activity

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: A canary in the coal mine

options.label: B
options.text: White surfaces, like snow and ice

options.text: The increased heat is reflected back into space

options.label: C
options.text: The increased heat is trapped by the atmosphere

options.label: D
options.text: The increased heat is dissipated into the ocean

options.label: C
options.text: Forming a layer in the atmosphere, acting as a buffer between the arctic air and the relatively warmer air underneath

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on the atmosphere

options.label: D
options.text: It has a negative impact on the atmosphere

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It destabilizes the system by enabling larger and larger deviations

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on the system

options.label: D
options.text: It has a negative impact on the system

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: They may have no effect on jet stream winds and atmospheric circulation

options.label: B
options.text: Short-term fluctuations becoming persistent warm snaps, cool waves, wet conditions, and dry conditions

options.label: C
options.text: Short-term fluctuations becoming persistent unstable conditions

options.label: D
options.text: Short-term fluctuations becoming persistent cold snaps, heat waves, and droughts

options.text: That it has no effect on the rest of the planet

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: It encourages stability by pushing a system towards equilibrium

options.label: B
options.text: It destabilizes the system by enabling larger and larger deviations

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on the system

options.label: D
options.text: It has a negative impact on the system

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: D

title: The great conspiracy against Julius Caesar - Kathryn Tempest

multiple-choice.question: Who claimed descent from Lucius Junius Brutus, who helped overthrow the tyrannical king Tarquin the Proud?

options.label: C
options.text: Julius Caesar and Pompey the Great

options.text: The rise of the Roman Republic

options.label: B
options.text: The decline of the Roman Empire

options.label: D
options.text: The end of the Republic and the concentration of power under the office of Emperor

options.text: The rise of the Roman Republic, the decline of the Roman Empire, and the death of Brutus

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The interpretation of Brutus, the legacy of Julius Caesar, and the legacy of the Roman Empire

options.label: D
options.text: The price of liberty, the conflict between personal loyalties and universal ideals, and unintended consequences
